hypothesis.title: Frequency-research vs Topic Research Controlled Comparison
hypothesis.question: How does tuning strategy (72-EDO vs 19-EDO vs 31-EDO) influence perceived consonance, roughness, and continuity in a controlled harmonic micro-study?
hypothesis.hypothesis: If we render one identical arrangement with tuning strategy (72-EDO vs 19-EDO vs 31-EDO) while holding all other musical factors fixed, then listener ratings will show a consistent ordering in consonance and roughness between versions, because interval-ratio alignment and temperament error distribution change partial overlap and beating behavior.
hypothesis.rationaleMd:
Selected sources converge on ratio-based and temperament-based explanations for consonance and roughness [S1, S2, S6].

The context includes explicit comma/temperament and interval evidence that supports a controlled comparison where only the tuning variable changes [S1, S2, S6, S7, S3, S8].

Falsification criterion: if blinded ratings show no stable ordering across versions, or if roughness notes fail to cluster by version, the hypothesis is not supported.

recipe.title: Frequency-research Comparison Micro-Study
recipe.bodyMd:
## Goal
Evaluate tuning strategy (72-EDO vs 19-EDO vs 31-EDO) under controlled musical conditions using a blinded comparison design.

## Shared Arrangement
- Tempo: 82 BPM
- Meter: 4/4
- Length: 24-32 bars
- Keep MIDI notes, sound sources, automation, and mix balance identical across versions.

## Variable Under Test
- Change only: tuning strategy (72-EDO vs 19-EDO vs 31-EDO)
- Keep all non-target variables fixed.

## Evaluation
- Blind-label exports and rate: consonance, roughness/beating, and continuity.
- Annotate bar/chord locations where roughness is strongest.

Evidence basis: [S1, S2, S6, S7, S3, S8].
